bibl.note: 1863 March 28 Southgate Cregmile in Murfreesboro, Tenn., to his Mother (Eleanor Griffin). Assures her that all there are well. Because there are Rebels within two miles of their picket lines, they are moving the camp closer to the commander's headquarters. Even though music and newspapers are the major ongoing camp distractions, he wishes he had better access to certain Ohio newspapers. Will send her the words to a couple of songs heard often in camp and suggests she let some of those totally opposing the war in general (Copperheads) read them. Urges her to write soon.

div.p: I now seat my seff once more to rite you a few lines to let you know that we are all well. we have been working to day Clearing off Camping ground we are a going to move closer to turn be four Gen. Negley head Quarters. the rebles has moved up with in to miles of our picket lines. we keep the music going on study now we take in plenty of Diserters from the reble army. I receved to papers to day that was sent to me thay have been
on the road a good while the papers was dated the 16th of Feb. we get the Gazette here every day only Forty eight hours olde I woulde like to have the Hamilton paper or the Oxford paper.
I will send you a copple of songs that going the rounds in Camp.
there is one of them you ought to let some of them Copperheads reidd it and see how thay would like it
I cant think of any thing mulchto rite a bout so I will stop rite soon
